column2: 'Please, sir, may I speak to you?'

column2: Mr. Upton was coming out of church after a choir practice, when Teddy accosted him.

column2: 'You may walk home with me and speak to me as much as you like.'
column3: 'You may walk home with me and speak to me as much as you like.'

column2: And so they sauntered up the shady lane, the old rector with his head bent and his hands crossed behind him, and the boy all eager excitement and motion, with suppressed importance in his tone.

column2: 'I want you to give me a name for my enemy, please, sir.'

column2: Mr. Upton looked amused.

column2: 'Have you had any battles with him yet?'

column2: 'I think I had one yesterday.

column2: May I tell you?
column3: May I tell you?

column2: Granny was very angry with me because I had made Uncle Jake's best handkerchief into a banner of love.
column3: Granny was very angry with me because I had made Uncle Jake's best handkerchief into a banner of love.

column2: I didn't really think it was naughty.

column2: I wrote "Love" in ink right across it; and I took such pains, for I wanted to show it to Nancy.

column2: And when I got home granny was so angry that she took me by the collar and she locked me into the back kitchen; and mother was out, and I cried, I was so miserable.
column3: And when I got home granny was so angry that she took me by the collar and she locked me into the back kitchen; and mother was out, and I cried, I was so miserable.

column2: Granny said I would come to the workhouse; she called me the wickedest, mischievousest boy she'd ever seen, and said she would like to give me a good whipping.
column3: Granny said I would come to the workhouse; she called me the wickedest, mischievousest boy she'd ever seen, and said she would like to give me a good whipping.

column2: And at last I got tired of being miserable, and I looked about, and I saw the window was partly open, so I climbed up, and then I thought I would jump out and run away across the fields till mother came home.
column3: And at last I got tired of being miserable, and I looked about, and I saw the window was partly open, so I climbed up, and then I thought I would jump out and run away across the fields till mother came home.

column2: And I was very happy then, and I jumped right out, and then I remembered, but I didn't want to go back again.'

column2: But Mr. Upton's thoughts were far away by this time, and presently he said, as if to himself, '"The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death." "Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors, through Him that loved us." It is a fight with certain victory ahead; then why do we fail?'

column2: 'Shall I fail?' questioned a soft voice by his side.

column2: '"Without Me ye can do nothing." That's our Captain's word: if you fight without Him, you are done for.'

column2: 'But then, of course, my Captain won't let me be beaten, if I stick close to Him.'
column3: 'But then, of course, my Captain won't let me be beaten, if I stick close to Him.'

column2: And so they talked, a strange couple; but the younger of them had a faith which the elder might envy, and a grasp of the unseen that the ripest saint could not surpass.

column2: Not long after this, Teddy and his schoolfellows were having a delightful afternoon in the woods.

column2: It was Saturday afternoon, and they were playing their favourite war game, Teddy, of course, being prime instigator of the whole affair.

column2: At length Teddy announced his intention of going off on an expedition as a scout, and on Nancy's insisting that she should come too, the two children started, made their way out of the wood and down to the banks of the stream, which soon joined the river.
column3: At length Teddy announced his intention of going off on an expedition as a scout, and on Nancy's insisting that she should come too, the two children started, made their way out of the wood and down to the banks of the stream, which soon joined the river.

column2: 'What have we to do?' asked Nancy.
column3: 'What have we to do?' asked Nancy.

column2: 'It's great fun.
column3: 'It's great fun.

column2: You see, every one we meet is an enemy, and we have to get past them without them seeing us; we must crawl through the long grass, or we must climb a tree, or get through the bushes; all kinds of adventures we have.'
column3: You see, every one we meet is an enemy, and we have to get past them without them seeing us; we must crawl through the long grass, or we must climb a tree, or get through the bushes; all kinds of adventures we have.'

column2: 'And if we don't meet anybody?'
column3: 'And if we don't meet anybody?'

column2: 'That's why I came down this way: there are always a lot of people fishing in the river.
column3: 'That's why I came down this way: there are always a lot of people fishing in the river.

column2: Now look out, don't you talk loud, and step softly. Just think that the first person who sees us will shoot us dead.'
column3: Now look out, don't you talk loud, and step softly. Just think that the first person who sees us will shoot us dead.'

column2: 'But they won't.'

column2: 'You must make believe they will.' Teddy's tone was stern, and Nancy was too occupied in holding her hat on her head as they crept through some low bushes to advance any more sceptical opinions.
column3: 'You must make believe they will.' Teddy's tone was stern, and Nancy was too occupied in holding her hat on her head as they crept through some low bushes to advance any more sceptical opinions.

column2: And then suddenly, a short time after, they came upon a fisherman.
column3: And then suddenly, a short time after, they came upon a fisherman.

column2: It was only a burly farmer, who was evidently making a day of it, for he sat under the shade of a tree with the remnants of a substantial lunch around him; his fishing-rod was in his hand, but the line was out of the water, and he, with head thrown back and mouth wide open, was fast asleep.

column2: 'If he wakes, all is up with us; now let's get past him on tiptoe.'
column3: 'If he wakes, all is up with us; now let's get past him on tiptoe.'

column2: This was accomplished safely; but having passed him Teddy stood still, and the spirit of mischief seized hold of him.

column2: Turning to Nancy, he said, with sparkling eyes, 'What fun to take him prisoner and tie him up to the tree with his own fishing-line!
column3: Turning to Nancy, he said, with sparkling eyes, 'What fun to take him prisoner and tie him up to the tree with his own fishing line!

column2: He's an enemy; I really think it's our duty to do it.

column2: You stay here and watch me.'

column2: Deftly and quickly Teddy set to work, but when he had once passed the line round the farmer's body and the tree, he had no difficulty in finishing the work he had begun.

column2: Dancing like an elf with the line in his hand, he spun round and round the tree till the line was wound round to its very last extremity, and the farmer looked like some big bluebottle fly entangled in the fine meshes of a spider's web.

column2: The children ran back to their playfellows considerably sobered by their experience, and Teddy very soon made his way home, and told his mother all that had befallen him.
column3: The children ran back to their playfellows considerably sobered by their experience, and Teddy very soon made his way home, and told his mother all that had befallen him.

column2: 'It's dreadful difficult to remember in time, mother.
column3: 'It's dreadful difficult to remember in time, mother.

column2: I'm not a very good soldier, am I? Do you think I ought to love old Farmer Green?
column3: I'm not a very good soldier, am I? Do you think I ought to love old Farmer Green?

column2: If you won't tell any one, I've been having a talk with Ipse--he's my enemy, Mr. Upton told me about--and he--he hates Farmer Green; but I tell him the banner is "Love," and we must try to love him; and how can I show him I love him, mother?'
column3: If you won't tell any one, I've been having a talk with i p s e-he's my enemy, mr Upton told me about-and he-he hates Farmer Green; but I tell him the banner is "Love," and we must try to love him; and how can I show him I love him, mother?'

column2: 'I think you must wait a little, sonny.
column3: 'I think you must wait a little, sonny.

column2: Don't do anything just yet, but try and not have angry thoughts about him.
column3: Don't do anything just yet, but try and not have angry thoughts about him.

column2: You know it was very naughty of you to act so.
column3: You know it was very naughty of you to act so.

column2: I am not a bit surprised that he lost his temper over it.'
column3: I am not a bit surprised that he lost his temper over it.'
